A campsite's feeble electric signlight flickers at the edge of the meadow.

# BITSY VERSION 2.1

! ROOM_FORMAT 1

POS 0 15,7

DLG a
You stop to make your bows before the monolith. Its spinning metal eye whines and flickers in the dark, and you think, perhaps, that it fixes on you for a moment before resuming its roving focus on the fields down the hill. In the private dark here at the edge of the campsite, you use the stone's soft glow to count your coins, bite them, check they're real. You'll leave one here as charity in the morning, when the monolith goes silent and the fog rises from the fields with the frigid dawn.

DLG t
Lucky to find some electric light out here.

DLG s
Lucky to find some electric light out here.

DLG r
Wire's buzzing.

DLG o
The shelter will be full tonight.

DLG p
The shelter will be full tonight.

DLG q
This traveler stares fixedly at the monolith and smokes like a ship's engine. She won't spare you a word or a glance, but she does offer a wordless grunt.

DLG n


DLG m
Wire's buzzing.

DLG l
This traveler dozes in the glow of the monolith and mutters in his sleep. You can see the medallion around his neck-- a stonechaser. You wonder how far he's come to visit this damp and grimy little ruin.

DLG k
Generator smells of fuel.

DLG h
The bucket for hand-washing is fill of extremely cold, clear water. A crab for blessings scuttles at the bottom.

DLG g
The old hound coughs out a low, tired bark as a halfhearted greeting.

DLG f
The shelter-keeper invites you to wash your hands and sit by the fire. "There's a log for you, wanderer. I've got a teakettle inside, if you brought any leaves."

DLG e
The fire mutters low in the pit. The frost on your cloak melts and shines.

DLG i
"Uuhf. Lucky you missed dinner. Shelter-keeper cooked something I don't recognize, and now I'm too sick to sleep."

DLG j
Bundled jackets and a sleeping-roll.

DLG u
Lucky to find some electric light out here.

DLG c
You stop to make your bows before the monolith. Its spinning metal eye whines and flickers in the dark, and you think, perhaps, that it fixes on you for a moment before resuming its roving focus on the fields down the hill. In the private dark here at the edge of the campsite, you use the stone's soft glow to count your coins, bite them, check they're real. You'll leave one here as charity in the morning, when the monolith goes silent and the fog rises from the fields with the frigid dawn.

DLG d
You stop to make your bows before the monolith. Its spinning metal eye whines and flickers in the dark, and you think, perhaps, that it fixes on you for a moment before resuming its roving focus on the fields down the hill. In the private dark here at the edge of the campsite, you use the stone's soft glow to count your coins, bite them, check they're real. You'll leave one here as charity in the morning, when the monolith goes silent and the fog rises from the fields with the frigid dawn.
